questions.question: Which of the following parasites is ovoviviparous?

Identify the helminth from the life cycle given below.Free-Living CycleInfective filariform larvaepenetrate the intact skin ofthe definitive host.Rhabditiformlarvae developinto filariform (13)larvaeRhabditiformlarvae hatch fromembryonated eggsEggs are producedby fertilizedfemale wormsto filariform larvaeODPDXDevelopmentinto free-livingadult worms
questions.explanation: The image shows the life cycle of Strongyloides stercoralis.The infective form of strongyloides is the filariform larva. Infection occurs through penetration ofthe skin by larvae in the soil. Then, they migrate to the small intestine.The larvae molt twice and become adult female worms in the small intestine. The eggs laid in themucosa of the intestine hatch immediately releasing the rhabditiform larva (L1 stage). Theserhabditiform larvae in the bowel can develop directly into filariform larvae that penetrate thecolonic wall or perianal skin and enter the circulation to repeat the migration. This establishesongoing internal reinfection.The rhabditiform larva can be seen on microscopic examination of stool.

questions.question: AUTOINFECTIONParasitic CycleThe filariform larvae migrate by variouspathways to the small intestine where theybecome adults.Dogs may also serve asdefinitive hostsAutoinfection:Rhabditiform larvae inlarge intestine becomeflariform, penetrateintestinal mucosa forperianal skin) andmigrate to otherorgansParasitic adultfemale in smallIntestine4Rhabditiform larvaein the intestine areexcreted in stoolEggs deposited in intestinal mucosaRhabditiform larvae hatch and migrateto intestinal lumen.Infective stageDiagnostic stageCDC575A 24-year-old patient presented with complaints of diarrhea, vomiting, and abdominal painfor 1 week. The stool microscopy revealed the following. What is the appropriate treatmentfor this condition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and the stool microscopy showing the rhabditiform larva of S.stercoralis are suggestive of strongyloidiasis. The most appropriate treatment for this conditionwould be ivermectin.Strongyloidiasis is caused by Strongyloides stercoralis. It is generally a benign and asymptomaticcondition. In some cases, there may be cutaneous, pulmonary, and intestinal manifestations.

questions.question: An 8-year-old child was brought with complaints of perianal itching which is worse in thenight. The scotch tape method demonstrates eggs as shown in the image given below. What isthe most likely causative agent?576
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario of perianal itching and the scotch tape microscopy showing the eggsare suggestive of infestation with pinworm (Enterobius vermicularis).The eggs of pinworm are plano-convex in shape, colorless, non-bile stained, and float in thesaturated salt solution. Eggshell is double layered and relatively thick, though transparent.Since pinworms are not released in feces, the diagnosis cannot be made by conventional fecal ovaand parasite tests. NIH swab method and the scotch tape method are used for the collection ofspecimens.The NIH swab (National Institutes of Health, USA) consists of a glass rod, at one end of which apiece of transparent cellophane is attached with a rubber band. The cellophane part is used forswabbing by rolling over the perianal area. It is returned to the test tube and sent to thelaboratory. The cellophane piece is detached, spread over a glass side, and examinedmicroscopically.The image given below shows the NIH swab.588MAOMARROWRubberstopperGlass rodTest tubeRubber bandCellophaneIn scotch tape method, the tape is firmly pressed against the anal margin, covering all sides. Thetape is transferred to a glass slide with sticky side down. Then a drop of toluene is added forclearing and examined under the microscope.Scotch tape method©MARROWWThe below image shows the life cycle of Enterobius vermicularis.589Embryonated eggsingested by humandEggs on perianal foldsLarvae inside the eggsmature within 4 to 6 hours.Infective Staged= Diagnostic StageLarvae hatchin small intestineAdults in lumenof cecumGravid q migrates5to perianal regionat night to lay eggs

questions.question: Which of the following helminthic infections that is commonly transmitted by soil, ischaracterized by the egg in stool as shown in the image below?
questions.explanation: The given image shows the egg of Trichuris trichiura (whipworm).The characteristic features of whipworm eggs are:•Eggs are barrel-shaped in the middle with a projecting mucus plug at each pole containing anunsegmented ovum. The plugs are colorless.• They float in the saturated salt solution.•It has a triple shell, the outermost layer of which is stained brown.They are commonly transmitted by soil. The eggs passed in the stool areunembryonated. Microscopic identification of the eggs in a stool specimen is diagnostic ofwhipworm infection.In moderate infections of 20 adult worms or less, the worms are confined to the caecum andascending colon. The symptoms include epigastric and lower abdominal pain, diarrhoea (rarelybloody), vomiting, flatulence and distention, weight loss, and increased blood and iron loss.In heavy infections of 200 adult worms or more (trichuriasis dysentery syndrome), the worms arein the distal colon and rectum. The symptoms include bloody diarrhoea with profuse mucus,abdominal pain, tenesmus, weight loss leading to cachexia, severe anemia, and rectal prolapse. Onexamination, clubbing may be present. Blood investigations may show moderate eosinophilia.Chronic infection leads to growth retardation and nutritional deficiencies. Around 0.005 ml ofblood is lost per day per worm. In heavy infections, as much as 4 to 5 ml can be lost per day perworm.Treatment is mebendazole or albendazole.

questions.question: A college student came to the OPD with fever and muscle aches. He tells you he hadconsumed smoked pork at a party 2 weeks back. Following this, he had developed abdominalcramps and diarrhea which had resolved on their own. CBC revealed eosinophilia and themuscle biopsy showed the following finding. What is the causative organism?
questions.explanation: 590The given clinical scenario and muscle biopsy showing larvae are suggestive of trichinellosis. It iscaused by Trichinella spiralis.Trichinella spiralis is known as the pork worm since the infection is acquired by consuming rawor undercooked pork. The initial infection presents with diarrhea and abdominal pain. In the laterphase of the infection, the larvae move from the intestines into the circulation and migrate intomuscles where they are encysted. This causes symptoms like fever and myalgia.These larvae are calcified in about 5-6 months. Eosinophilia caused by parasitic infection alsocomes down after 6 months.Detection of spiral larva in muscle tissue is done by performing a muscle biopsy. Deltoid, biceps,gastrocnemius, or pectoralis muscles are usually selected for biopsy..Other parasites that can be demonstrated in a muscle biopsy are:• T. solium• T. cruzi (amastigote)The image below shows Trichinella spiralis larvae within the muscle.

questions.question: In a patient with a positive Bachman intradermal test, which of the following infections willyou suspect?
questions.explanation: Bachman intradermal test is used for the diagnosis of trichinellosis.In this test, 1:5,000 or 1:10,000 dilution of the trichinella larval antigen is injected intradermally.An erythematous wheal appears in positive cases within 15-20 minutes. The test remains positivefor years after infection.

questions.question: Identify the organism shown in this image.
questions.explanation: 591The given image shows the Ascaris lumbricoides (roundworm). It is the most common of humanhelminths and is distributed worldwide.Adult worms live in the small intestine (85% in the jejunum and 15% in the ileum). Theroundworm, Ascaris lumbricoides is the largest nematode parasite in the human intestine.The adult worms are large cylindrical worms, with tapering ends, the anterior end being morepointed than the posterior.Man is the natural host. There is no intermediate host.Infection occurs through food or water contaminated with nightsoil or human feces containingeggs of ascaris. The eggs contain the infective rhabditiform larva.

questions.question: A 9-year-old boy was brought to the casualty with fever and colicky abdominal pain. An erectX-ray abdomen showed multiple air-fluid levels. Stool examination revealed the followingegg. Which of the following is false about the organism causing this condition?579

options.D: Egg containing L1 larva is infective

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of ascariasis caused by Ascarislumbricoides. Embryonated egg containing the L3 larva is the infective form.Man is the only natural host. There is no intermediate host. The infection is acquired via theconsumption of food or water contaminated with eggs. The eggs hatch after reaching theduodenum to release the larvae. These penetrate the intestinal mucosa and enter the portalvessels. From the liver, larvae reach the systemic circulation, lungs and then reach the smallintestine to produce symptoms.Clinical features:Due to the migrating larvae:• Fever• Dry cough• Asthmatic wheezing• Loeffler's syndromeDue to the adult worm:• Asymptomatic• Nutritional effects - protein-energy malnutrition, Vitamin A deficiency• Toxic effects urticaria, angioedema due to hypersensitivity-• Mechanical effects colicky abdominal pain, volvulus, and intestinal obstruction-• Ectopic ascariasis - acute biliary obstruction, pancreatitis, and obstructive appendicitis.The life cycle of Ascaris lumbricoides is given below.592ODPDxEmbryonatedegg with L3larvaAscaris lumbricoides4Ingestion ofembryonated eggsLarvae are coughed upand swallowed, re-enteringthe gastrointestinal tract.Maturation proceeds in thesmall intestine.CD CHatched larvae entercirculation and migrateto lungs.Adults in small intestineInfective stageDiagnostic stage5Fertilized eggUnfertilized egg(will not undergofurther development)

questions.question: What is the most common cause for visceral larva migrans?
questions.explanation: The most common cause for visceral larva migrans is Toxocara canis. It occurs most commonly inchildren and presents as fever, hepatosplenomegaly, and pneumonitis.Larva migrans is generally seen when human infection occurs with nonhuman species ofnematodes. It can be classified into cutaneous or visceral types, depending on whether the larvalmigration takes place in the skin or in deeper tissues.Visceral larva migrans is caused by the migration of nematode larvae that are acquired via the oralroute. Cutaneous larva migrans is caused by the migration of nematode larvae (mostcommonly Ancylostoma braziliense) that are acquired via skin penetration.Patients having visceral larva migrans may develop neurological disturbances (neural larvamigrans) and endophthalmitis (ophthalmic larva migrans).Differences between cutaneous larva migrans and visceral larva migrans:Cutaneous larva migransTissue involvedSkinInfecting Organis Mostly by non-human nematmPortal of EntryodesPenetration of skinEosinophiliaMildSerodiagnosisNot developedTreatmentThiabendazoleVisceral larva migransVarious organs of the body like the liver, lungs, and eyesMostly by non-human nematodes (mainly by dog and cat)Ingestion of infected eggsPersistent highWell developedDiethylcarbamazine and prednisolone593

questions.question: A middle-aged woman comes to the OPD with complaints of weakness for the past 3 months.She is diagnosed to have microcytic hypochromic anemia. The stool microscopy reveals thefollowing. What is the most probable causative agent?580

options.B: Strongyloides stercoralisEnterobius vermicularisd) Ascaris lumbricoidesQuestion 12:A patient presented to the OPD with dry cough, low-grade fever and wheezing. He isdiagnosed with Loeffler's syndrome. Which of the following parasites does not cause this?a) Ascaris lumbricoidesb) Necator americanus

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario of iron deficiency anemia and the stool microscopy showing the egg issuggestive of infection by Ancylostoma duodenale.Eggs of both Ancylostoma duodenale (old world hookworm) and Necator americanus (new worldhookworm) are identical.The hookworm eggs are oval or elliptical in shape, colorless, and non-bile stained. It has a thintransparent hyaline shell membrane. The ovum is segmented with 4 to 8 blastomeres. There is aclear space between the segmented ovum and eggshell. Eggs float in the saturated salt solution.Humans are infected when filariform larvae in moist soil penetrate the skin or subcutaneoustissue. The larvae are then carried in the venous circulation to the heart and lungs, where theymay cause mild transient pneumonitis or bronchitis. They migrate up the respiratory tract to thepharynx, are swallowed, and reach the small intestine producing epigastric pain, dyspepsia,nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.A. duodenale or N. americanus ingest blood, secrete anticoagulants, and interfere with theabsorption of iron, B12, and folic acid. This leads to iron deficiency anemia and protein-energymalnutrition resulting from blood loss.The average blood loss of the host per worm per day is 0.2 mL with Ancylostoma duodenaleand 0.03 mL with Necator americanus.

questions.question: A 27-year-old woman had gone on a trek in the Amazon rainforest. A month later shepresented to the OPD with the following lesion which was painful and pruritic. Her systemicexamination was normal. Which of the following organisms is most likely to cause thiscondition?581
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and the image showing serpiginous skin lesions are suggestive ofcutaneous larva migrans or creeping eruption or ground itch. This is most commonly causedby Ancylostoma braziliense.Cutaneous larva migrans is caused by non-human hookworms like Ancylostoma braziliense andAncylostoma caninum. It is acquired via direct skin contact with soil contaminated by dog orcat feces. The larvae remain confined to the outer layers of skin, as they are unable to penetratethe basement membrane of the human skin.It presents as erythematous, pruritic papules at the site of entry and serpiginous tracks in theepidermis. The symptoms begin to appear within the first two weeks of the patient's return from atropical or endemic country. The larval track progresses at approximately 1 cm/h with cutaneouslesions only progressing a few millimeters to a few centimeters daily.Diagnosis is based mainly on clinical features.The treatment includes:• Thiabendazole topical application.• Albendazole 400mg/day X 3 days or•• Ivermectin 200mcg/kg single dose statThe differences between cutaneous larva migrans and visceral larva migrans are:Note: A rapidly moving lesion (10cm/hr) produced by Strongyloides stercoralis is known as larvacurrens (running larva). It occurs as an otherwise asymptomatic lesionin immunocompetent individuals. In immunocompromised, hyper-infestation syndrome occurswith paralytic ileus and secondary Gram-negative sepsis.Cutaneous larva migransTissue involvedSkinInfecting Organis Mostly by non-human nematmodesPortal of EntryPenetration of skinEosinophiliaMildSerodiagnosisNot developedTreatmentThiabendazoleVisceral larva migransVarious organs of the body like the liver, lungs, and eyesMostly by non-human nematodes (mainly by dog and cat)Ingestion of infected eggsPersistent highWell developedDiethylcarbamazine and prednisolone

questions.question: Which the following filarial worms are non-pathogenic to humans?
questions.explanation: Mansonella ozzardi is generally non-pathogenic to humans.595Option A: Onchocerca volvulus infection may manifest as skin nodules or onchocercoma whichare formed as a result of fibroblastic reaction around adult worms deep in the subcutaneoustissues. Microfilariae cause lesions in the skin and eyes.Options B and C: In lymphatic filariasis (Wuchereria and Brugia), the typical manifestations arecaused by the adult worms blocking lymph nodes and vessels. Microfilaria (larval form) areresponsible for allergic manifestations seen in occult filariasis.

questions.question: A 55-year-old man came to the hospital with complaints of progressive swelling of his legs.On examination, you note bilateral non-pitting edema of the lower limbs with thickening ofthe overlying skin. What is the best next step in the management of this patient?582
questions.explanation: The given clinical picture is suggestive of lymphatic filariasis (elephantiasis). The best next stepwould be to test the night blood for worms since the filarial species is nocturnally periodic(between 10 pm and 4 am) in India.Lymphatic filariasis is caused by Wuchereria bancrofti and Brugia malayi.Elephantiasis is a delayed sequel to repeated lymphangitis, obstruction, and lymphedema.Repeated leakage of lymph into tissues first results in lymphedema, then to elephantiasis.Diethylcarbamazine is the drug of choice.Option A: PCR is negative in chronic filariasis.Options B & D: Lymphangiography and lymphoscintigraphy may be used to demonstrateabnormal lymphatic urinary fistula leading to chyluria in chronic filariasis.

questions.question: A child from Bihar is brought to the AIIMS ER with a high-grade fever. On examination,bilaterally enlarged, tender inguinal lymph nodes are present. The peripheral smearexamination finding is shown in the image. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and the peripheral smear showing sheathed microfilaria with twonuclei at the tail tip is suggestive of infection with Brugia malayi.Acute infection may manifest as acute adenolymphangitis which is characterized by high fever,lymphatic inflammation (lymphangitis and lymphadenitis) and transient local edema. Themost commonly affected lymph nodes are inguinal nodes followed by axillary nodes whichbecome enlarged, painful and tender.The following are the characteristic features of microfilaria of Brugia malayi:• Smaller in size compared to microfilaria of W. bancrofti.• Shows kinks and secondary curves.•Cephalic space is longer.•Carries double stylets at the anterior end.• Nuclear column appears blurred in Giemsa-stained films.• Tail tip carries 2 distinct nuclei, one terminal and the other subterminal.The below image shows the microfilaria of Brugia malayi.596OMARROW-Subterminalnucleus-Terminalnucleus

questions.question: A patient from Kerala has presented to your OPD with fever. A magnified view of peripheralblood smear is shown below. Which of the following is false regarding the organism seen?

options.A: DEC provocation test is used to demonstrate microfilaria during the day
options.B: Second stage filariform larva is the infective form
options.C: Microfilaria is the major diagnostic form
options.D: Filarial stage of adult worms are responsible for disease

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario with a peripheral smear showing sheathed microfilaria with a pointedtail free of nuclei is suggestive of Wuchereria bancrofti. The third stage filariform larva is theinfective form.Wuchereria bancrofti infection is usually asymptomatic. The symptoms are due to obstruction oflymphatics by the filarial stage of adult worms.The lymphatic vessels of the male genitalia are most commonly affected in bancroftian filariasis,producing episodic funiculitis, epididymitis, and orchitis. Adenolymphangitis of the extremities isless common.Hydrocele is the most common sign of chronic bancroftian filariasis, followed by lymphedema,elephantiasis, and chyluria. The swelling involves the whole leg, the whole arm, the scrotum, thevulva, or the breast.DEC provocation test is used to demonstrate microfilaria during the day.The image below shows the life cycle of Wuchereria bancrofti.597Mosquito StagesMosquito takesa blood meal(13 larvae enter inHuman Stages8 Migrate to head andmosquito's proboscis6L1 larvaeL3 larvae2Adults in lymphatics3Adults produce sheathedmicrofilariae that migrateMosquito takesinto lymph and bloodchannelsMicrofilariae shed sheaths,pentrate mosquito's midgut,and migrate to thoracic musclesa blood mealngest microfa)A= Infective StageDiagnostic StageThe image below shows the difference between microfilaria of various filarial nematodes.Difference between microfilariafilarial nematodes.NocturnalWuchereria bancroftiiority - Sheathed, the tail-tip free fromCulex and Anopheles mosquito.nucleiBrugia malayNocturnal periodicity - Sheathed, two discrete nuclei,one at extreme tip and the other midway betweenthe tip and posterior column of nuclei- Vector: Mansonia and Aedes mosquito.Teduniaperiodicity- Vector:Loa JoaSheathed. nucleiChrysops (mangoupfly).the tail tipOMARRO \V

questions.question: A 54-year-old farmer from Assam presented with the finding shown in the image. He had also developed a painless swelling in his elbow 2 years back, which has gradually been increasing in size. Which of the following is the drug of choice to treat this condition?
questions.explanation: The clinical scenario and image showing sclerosing keratitis are suggestive of onchocerciasis (river blindness). The drug of choice is ivermectin. It is caused by Onchocerca volvulus. It is also known as convoluted filaria or blinding filaria. The vector is blackfly (Simulium species), which breed in fast-flowing rivers, and therefore the disease is most common along the course of rivers. Hence, it is also called river blindness. The usual presentation is formation of a subcutaneous nodule or onchocercoma. It is a firm, non-tender nodule arising from bony sites like the scalp, elbow, ribs, and iliac crest. It is associated with pruritus and rashes. The microfilaria in the eyes cause photophobia and gradual loss of vision. The most severe manifestation is sclerosing keratitis and chorioretinitis, which causes blindness. It is the 2nd major infective cause of blindness in the world after trachoma. Suramin and diethylcarbamazine (DEC) were used earlier but are not used nowadays. DEC destroys microfilariae but usually causes a Mazzotti reaction, consisting of pruritus, rash, lymphadenopathy, fever, hypotension, and occasionally, eye damage. Note: Onchocerciasis is not endemic in India, but sporadic cases have been reported from North-Eastern India.

questions.question: A middle-aged woman presents to your clinic with photosensitivity, redness, and watering ofthe eyes for the last 2 days. She shows you this photo of a swelling in her hand that had arisen2 weeks back but disappeared in just 3 days. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and the image showing Calabar swelling is suggestive of loiasis causedby Loa loa.Calabar swellings are temporary foci of inflammation that appear as Loa loa wanders through thesubcutaneous tissues. They are up to 3 cm in size and are also called fugitive swellings becausethey disappear in a few days only to reappear elsewhere.Loa loa is transmitted by the bite of Chrysops species (deerflies). The infective form is the thirdstage microfilaria. After entry into human skin, it grows into an adult worm.The ocular manifestations occur when the worm reaches the subconjunctival tissue during itswanderings. They include:• Granuloma in bulbar conjunctiva•• Painless edema of the eyelids•Proptosis.The image below shows Calabar swelling.The image below shows a live, adult Loa loa in the anterior chamber of the eye.599

questions.question: Which of the following is also known as Weingarten syndrome?
questions.explanation: Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia is also known as Weingarten syndrome.Tropical eosinophilia occurs as a result of hypersensitivity reaction to microfilarial antigens andnot directly due to lymphatic involvement. It is a manifestation of occult filariasis(Meyer's-Kouwenaar syndrome).Clinical features of occult filariasis include massive eosinophilia and hepatosplenomegaly.Synonyms of tropical pulmonary eosinophilia include -•Weingarten syndrome••Pseudo-tuberculosis of the lung⚫ Eosinophilic pseudo-leukemia•Tropical eosinophilic asthma• Frimodt-Moller and Barton's syndrome

questions.question: Which of the following is known as serpent worm?
questions.explanation: Dracunculus medinensis is known as serpent worm.It is a viviparous nematode.This has been eradicated from India and all of the southeast Asian region in the year 2000.

questions.question: Match the following parasites with their respective hosts:
questions.explanation: 600ParasiteDefinitive host First intermediate hostDiphyllobothri HumansCyclopsumParagonimusHumansSnailFasciolaSheep and huSnailmansBrugiaHumansMansonia mosquitoSecond intermediate hostCyclops and fishCrayfish and crabAquatic vegetations601
